abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is highly satisfactory,
            and the sustainability rating is highly satisfactory.
            Overall performance of both the world Bank and the borrower
            is satisfactory. This project was the only Bank-funded
            blindness control project in the world, apart from the River
            Blindness Control Project in Africa. At the time of
            preparation, therefore, the Project could not draw from
            lessons from previous Bank experience. However, the Danida
            experience of implementing similar pilot projects in India
            provided valuable guidance, and many successful Danida
            initiatives were incorporated into project design, as has
            been pointed out earlier. The 8-year experience of
            implementing the project yields lessons that would be useful
            for other health sector projects in India. These lessons
            include: developing guidelines that were effectively
            implemented to involve nongovernmental organizations and the
            private service in service delivery, particularly in the
            peripheral areas, expanded the reach of the program in
            previously underserved areas and proved cost-effective. The
            development and utilization of monitoring tools such as the
            Rapid Assessment Survey and the National Survey can help in
            streamlining the program, identifying problem areas and
            organizing an effective response. This project has been
            leveraged to build the financial and management capacity of
            the states and improve service delivery. This report also
            makes the case for designing a context-specific package of
            services for remote areas. The main stakeholders should be
            involved in project design and beneficiary assessments
            designed that address issues of gender disparity, low
            literacy, poverty, and lack of motivation, and cultural and
            social variabilities--which all can adversely affect
            utilization of services. Operational lessons note the
            disparity between project and non-project states that was
            made more obvious by with additional funding and technical
            assistance, and encourages the government to intervene to
            balance this difference. The administrative, infrastructure,
            and technical inputs of the project considerably
            strengthened the capacity of the National Program for the
            Control of Blindness (NPCB) to manage other emerging causes
            of blindness such as refractive error, childhood blindness,
            and glaucoma.

18152569.theme: Injuries and non-communicable diseases,Health system performance,Indigenous peoples,Participation and civic engagement

abstracts.cdata!:
The Blindness Control Project will help
            improve the National Program for the Control of
            Blindness' (NPCB's) quality of service and expand
            its treatment capacity by: (a) enhancing quality of care and
            expanding service delivery through new strategies, policies,
            technical and operational norms; increased use of modern
            surgical techniques; and expanded coverage of rural and
            isolated populations with extensive Non Governmental
            Organization (NGO) and private sector involvement; (b)
            developing human resources for eye care delivery by
            strengthening selected training institutions, upgrading the
            skills of ophthalmic and health personnel, and providing
            management training for Central, State and District project
            managers; (c) promoting outreach activities and public
            awareness by supporting NGO's and community
            involvement, and raising awareness about cataract blindness
            through mass and traditional folk media, and interpersonal
            communications; and (d) developing institutional capacity at
            the Central, State and District levels, developing
            collaborative mechanisms with the nongovernment sectors,
            introducing measurable monitoring mechanisms, and conducting
            operations research.
